newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: NYMEX aims to launch Asia-specific energy futures.
newsitem.headline: NYMEX aims to launch Asia-specific energy futures.

text.p: The New York Mercantile Exchange (NYMEX) said on Wednesday it was working to launch an Asia-specific futures energy contract to be traded on its ACCESS screen-based system.
NYMEX President Patrick Thompson said research was at an early stage and he did not expect a proposal on a specific futures product to emerge for another year.
NYMEX has set up an advisory panel of traders to help mould the new product.
Speaking to reporters at the Asia-Pacific Petroleum Conference in Singapore, Thompson said the contract would probably be crude or gas oil based, with a cash, rather than delivery, settlement.
He said the discussions with the advisory group so far indicated the market for the new product should reach three to six months forward.
The Singapore International Monetary Exchange (SIMEX) has a dormant fuel oil futures contract, which it is revamping to increase trader interest.
A gas oil futures contract on SIMEX, launched in 1991, was delisted in 1993 because it was not being activiely traded.
"The biggest worrying factor is that there has been some failures in the past in the midst of a very growing market," Thompson said.
But he said he was confident futures markets were needed in the Asian energy sector because of its ballooning growth, increasing energy price volatility and worries about price manipulation.

"All of that would imply that the industry itself has a desire to create some vehicle which would be able to provide, on the one hand risk management and on the other hand price transparency," he said.
